pr_title: Issue #5089: LineLength measures Java characters, not Unicode characters

timeline.message: Issue #5089: LineLength measures Java characters, not Unicode characters

timeline.bodyText:
I can only reproduce the issue with maven and not in Eclipse. Since I can't debug, I am starting to add more print outs to see the issue. I removed changes to CommonUtil and the issue remained.
Maven and Eclipse disagree on line index 4 and 6.
Eclipse says lengths are 2-6 bytes shorter than reported by maven.
Looking at maven alone, old code and new code always reported a length of 103 so I am not seeing why there wasn't a violation to begin with,
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText:
I opened the file in a hex editor and the line in question is 103 bytes (not include \n). This is the same size being reported in the code.
I believe the issue is the input file and that it may not be recognized in the right file format which you may be trying to use.
The bytes in question are: F0 9F 92 A9
Eclipse uses charset UTF-8. Maven uses charset windows-1252.

timeline.bodyText:
I don't see this is acceptable as it will clash with all other tests and not just this one. You don't even unset the property so you will be leaking into other tests. Even if you do unset, your not guaranteed your code will hit the unset even in the same test.
This has to be passed into the configuration object and set via checker property just like you set the max property for the check.
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText: I didn't feel good about this either, thanks for suggesting an alternative.

The reason root config has the parameter is to receive the child that will be connected to it. If we can remove the call to addChild and just pass the child to createRootConfig then we should. It all should amount to the same thing in the end.
